subject: Investing
title: Why Companies Go Public
description: One-minute skill: Why Companies Go Public.

hook.text: A startup needs $500 million to grow. Banks won't lend it. Selling stock to the public will.

buildup.text: An IPO â€” initial public offering â€” lets a company sell shares to raise capital from everyday investors.

discovery.text: Going public also lets early employees and investors cash out. Their sweat equity becomes real money.

twist.text: Public companies must disclose finances every quarter. Privacy disappears the moment you list shares.

climax.text: Some founders hate it. Dell went private in 2013 to escape quarterly pressure, then re-listed in 2018.

punchline.text: Going public trades privacy for capital. Not every company likes the deal.

quiz.question: What is the primary reason companies go public through an IPO?
options: To raise capital by selling shares
